comments:
Build ID: M20060921-0945

Steps To Reproduce:
1.I have a JDT project

2.Have some source files that produce some of the warnings in step 3.

3.Disable warnings (in the global configuration): 
   - Non-static access to static member
   - Serializable class without serialVersionUID

4.No warnings are shown in the problem view

5.When I open (or maybe modify) are source file that has some of the warnings, I can see this in the Problem view:
   - The serializable class ContenidoTextual does not declare a static final serialVersionUID field of type long	
   - The static method ejec(PreparedStatement, List) from the type EdicionTabla should be accessed in a static way	

6.The project has no specific warnings config.


More information:

If I clean the project, the warnings disappear.
For me this is a clear sign that this is an Eclipse bug.

Sorry, I was confused.
When I clean the project, a lot of warning appear, that I have disabled.
*** Bug 170172 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
*** Bug 170174 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Really strange, this is something which is supposed to work for a long time and nobody else complain about similar problem...

So, some questions to try to understand what happen there:
1) Are you sure you do not have a .settings/org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs file in your project?
2) When you disabled warnings in the global configuration, did you rebuild all projects?
3) Do you have any filter in your problem view?
4) May be warnings displayed in Problem Views are on compilation units of other projects which have overridden these options, can you verify this?

1) Here is the contents of my .settings/org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs:

#Wed Jun 21 15:48:11 CEST 2006
eclipse.preferences.version=1
org.eclipse.jdt.core.builder.cleanOutputFolder=clean
org.eclipse.jdt.core.builder.duplicateResourceTask=warning
org.eclipse.jdt.core.builder.invalidClasspath=ignore
org.eclipse.jdt.core.builder.resourceCopyExclusionFilter=*.launch,*.g,*.smap,*TokenTypes.txt
org.eclipse.jdt.core.circularClasspath=error
org.eclipse.jdt.core.classpath.exclusionPatterns=enabled
org.eclipse.jdt.core.classpath.multipleOutputLocations=enabled
org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.maxProblemPerUnit=100
org.eclipse.jdt.core.incompatibleJDKLevel=ignore
org.eclipse.jdt.core.incompleteClasspath=error

As you can see no custom warning config.

My project is a Java one, that has dependencies with other Java projects (with custom warning settings).  It has also a PyDev (Jython) nature, and an Antlr nature but this shouldn?t be relevant.

Here is my project config if needed:

2) Yes, I rebuild all projects

3) Yes I have a custom filter.  But this filter removes warnings, it doesn't add any new warnings.  I have tried to deactive the filter, and naturally I see more warnings, including the ones that shouldn't appear.

4) I'm absolutely sure I'm not mixing files in different projects.
I think Eclipse 3.2 didn't have this bug.
When I rebuild the other projects (at first I cleaned just one project), I'm receiving more annoying "deprecated" and "serialVersionID" warnings.  These ones are disabled in custom project settings.

If you have a .settings/org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs in your project, that means you have defined specific compiler options on your project. So, change workspace preferences has no effect on your project compiler preferences.

As compiler first uses specific project preferences when they are defined, it sounds normal that you still get the warnings while compiling...

The only way to avoid these warnings is either to change the project preferences  values for these options or simply remove them to use the workspace ones you changed before...

Agree to close?

Project specific settings can be for:

- Error/warnings
- Building
- JavaDoc
- ....

Each one can be controlled independently.
In my case, I have NO specific settings for warnings.
So it is normal to have a .settings/org.eclipse.jdt.core.prefs in my project.

If I restart Eclipse all these problems disappear!!!
JDT internal state must have been corrupted.
In addition, I could't resolve local names when debugging, and arguments were shown as "arg0", "arg1", ....  This happened even when I was compiling with full debug info.
This has also disappeared.

Very strange.

Can you attach the .log file from .metadata to see if we can get some clues there?

Created an attachment (id=56816)
Eclipse log file

The file you attached is not the last log file but an old one .bak_0.log. The last log file is ".log"... However, if I assume stack traces I see in this file can be related to your problem, it would say that the origin of the problem was a NPE in AJDT:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 2 75 2007-01-11 17:34:55.302
!MESSAGE Errors during build.
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.ajdt.core 2 75 2007-01-11 17:34:55.302
!MESSAGE Errors running builder "AspectJ Builder" on project Informix.
!SUBENTRY 1 org.eclipse.ajdt.core 2 75 2007-01-11 17:34:55.302
!MESSAGE java.lang.NullPointerException encountered while running AspectJ Builder.
!STACK 0
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.ajdt.core.builder.AJBuilder.updateJavaCompilerPreferences(AJBuilder.java:741)
	at org.eclipse.ajdt.core.builder.AJBuilder.build(AJBuilder.java:168)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run(BuildManager.java:603)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:167)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:201)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run(BuildManager.java:230)
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.SafeRunner.run(SafeRunner.java:37)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild(BuildManager.java:233)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuildLoop(BuildManager.java:252)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build(BuildManager.java:285)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.doBuild(AutoBuildJob.java:145)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.AutoBuildJob.run(AutoBuildJob.java:208)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)

My assumption is that AJDT builder tried to update preferences but crashed on this NPE and let the org.eclipse.jdt.core preferences in an unexpected state as we got an IllegalStateException just after:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.jface 4 2 2007-01-11 17:34:58.534
!MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug-in: "org.eclipse.jface".
!STACK 0
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Preference node "org.eclipse.jdt.core" has been removed.

Move to AJDT component for further investigation

I haven't provided you .log, because it only contains info about the session without the problem, after Eclipse was restarted.

The cause you have found sounds quite logical, but AJDT is used in another project, in the same workspace.

There are a number of exceptions in your log file, so there may be more than one problem here. Could you try closing your AspectJ projects and temporarily deactivating AJDT, and then see if you still get this problem? Also, which version of AJDT do you have installed?

Please could you try upgrading to either the latest release, AJDT 1.4.1, or the latest development build for Eclipse 3.2, which is AJDT 1.4.2.200701190932
( see http://www.eclipse.org/ajdt/downloads/ )

Also as above, could you help isolate the problem(s) between JDT, AJDT, Jython, etc, by temporarily disabling the appropriate features ( Help > Software Updates > Manage Configuration)

OK.

Luckily this problem has only happened to me just once.
